meals.strInstructions:
Wash 1 cup lentils (दाल) thoroughly and soak for 15–20 minutes.
Add the lentils to a pressure cooker with 3 cups water, turmeric powder (बेसार), and salt (नून).
Pressure cook until the lentils are completely soft.
Heat ghee (घ्यू) or oil (तेल) in a separate pan.
Add cumin seeds (जीरा) and let them crackle.
Add chopped onions (प्याज) and fry until golden brown.
Add minced garlic (लसुन), ginger (अदुवा), and chopped tomatoes (टमाटर).
Cook until the tomatoes become soft.
Add red chili powder (खुर्सानी पाउडर) and coriander powder (धनिया पाउडर) and mix well.
Add the cooked lentils to the tempering.
Add water to adjust the consistency as needed.
Bring to a boil and simmer for about 10 minutes.
Garnish with fresh cilantro (धनिया).
Wash 2 cups basmati rice (बासमती चामल) until the water runs clear.
Soak the rice for 20–30 minutes.
Add the rice to a pot with water.
Bring it to a boil on high heat.
Reduce the heat to low and cover the pot.
Cook until the rice is tender.
Let it rest for a few minutes before serving with the dal.

Add all-purpose flour (मैदा) and salt (नून) to a large bowl.
Gradually add water and knead into a smooth, firm dough.
Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
In a separate bowl, combine minced chicken (कुखुराको मासु) with finely chopped onions (प्याज), garlic (लसुन), and ginger (अदुवा).
Add soy sauce, salt (नून), black pepper (कालो मरिच), and a little oil (तेल).
Add chopped cilantro (धनिया) and green onions (हरियो प्याज).
Mix everything thoroughly until well combined.
Refrigerate the filling for 15 minutes to firm up.
Divide the dough into small balls.
Roll each ball into a thin circular wrapper.
Place a spoonful of filling in the center of each wrapper.
Fold and pleat the edges carefully to seal completely.
Grease the steamer basket with a little oil (तेल).
Arrange the momos without touching each other.
Steam until the wrappers become translucent and the filling is fully cooked.
Serve hot with tomato-based achar (टमाटरको अचार) for authentic Nepali flavor.

Soak rice (चामल) overnight for at least 8 hours to soften the grains.
Drain the rice and grind it into a smooth paste using very little water, ensuring a fine batter.
Transfer the batter to a large bowl.
Add sugar (चिनी), mashed banana (केरा), ghee (घ्यू), cardamom powder (इलाइची), and fennel seeds (सौंफ). Mix everything thoroughly.
Gradually add milk (दूध) to achieve a thick but flowing consistency that can be piped easily.
Cover the batter and let it ferment for 2–3 hours in a warm place for slight tang and flavor development.
Heat oil (तेल) in a deep kadhai or wok over medium-high heat until hot.
Pour the batter into a cloth piping bag or a bottle with a nozzle.
Once the oil is hot, reduce the heat to medium.
Pipe the batter in a circular motion directly into the oil to form ring shapes.
Fry until golden brown on one side.
Flip carefully and fry the other side until golden.
Remove the fried rings and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve hot or at room temperature as a sweet snack.

Soak dried gundruk (गुँद्रुक) in water for 15–20 minutes to soften it.
Squeeze out the excess water thoroughly.
Chop the gundruk into smaller pieces if needed.
Heat mustard oil (तेल) in a pan until it reaches the smoking point, then reduce the heat.
Add fenugreek seeds (मेथी) and let them splutter.
Add dried red chilies (सुक्खा खुर्सानी) and roast briefly to release aroma.
Add chopped onions (प्याज) and green chilies (हरियो खुर्सानी) and sauté until the onions soften.
Add minced garlic (लसुन) and ginger (अदुवा) and cook for about a minute.
Add the soaked and squeezed gundruk to the pan.
Mix well and cook on medium heat.
Add turmeric powder (बेसार) and salt (नून) to taste.
Add chopped tomatoes (टमाटर) and cook until they soften.
Cook for a few more minutes to blend the flavors.
Add fresh cilantro (धनिया) and chopped green onions.
Mix everything well and remove from heat.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice.

Cut the chicken (Kukhura) into medium-sized pieces.
In a bowl, mix yogurt (Dahi), freshly prepared ginger-garlic paste (Ado-Rosun ko Paste), lemon juice (Kagati ko Raso), and mustard oil (Teeu).
Add turmeric powder (Besisar), cumin powder (Jeera), coriander powder (Dhaniya), red chili powder (Khursani), and garam masala (Garam Masala).
Add salt (Namak) and mix well to form a smooth marinade.
Add the chicken pieces to the marinade and coat them thoroughly.
Cover and marinate for at least 4 hours or overnight in the refrigerator for best flavor.
Preheat the grill or oven to high heat.
Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto skewers, leaving small gaps for even cooking.
Grill, turning occasionally to ensure all sides are evenly cooked.
Baste with mustard oil (Teeu) during grilling to enhance flavor and prevent drying.
Cook until the chicken is fully cooked and slightly charred at the edges.
Serve hot with beaten rice (Chiura), tomato achar (Tamatir ko Achar), and onion rings (Pyaj ko Rings) for a complete Nepali-style meal.

Add puffed rice (Chiura) to a large bowl.
Add finely chopped onions (Pyaj), tomatoes (Tamatir), and green chilies (Hariyo Khursani).
Add boiled chickpeas (Chana).
Add chopped cilantro (Dhaniya).
Add freshly squeezed lemon juice (Kagati), salt, and chili powder (Khursani Powder) to taste.
Sprinkle chaat masala and cumin powder (Jeera) for authentic flavor.
Mix everything thoroughly so that all ingredients are evenly combined.
Top with sev (crispy noodles) for added crunch.
Serve immediately while the mixture is fresh and crunchy.
Optionally, add a few drops of mustard oil (Teeu) for a traditional Nepali taste.

Mix 9 types of beans: black gram (Urad), chickpeas (Chana), mung beans (Moong), black-eyed peas (Bodi), soybeans (Soya), kidney beans (Rajma), garden peas (Hariyo Bodi), lima beans (Sem), and Gahat (horse gram).
Soak the mixed beans overnight for at least 8 hours to soften and prepare for sprouting.
Drain the soaked beans and spread them on a damp cloth for 1–2 days until they sprout slightly.
Pressure cook the sprouted beans with water, turmeric, and salt until they are very soft.
Heat mustard oil in a pan until it shimmers.
Add cumin seeds (Jeera) and a pinch of asafoetida (Hing).
Add freshly prepared ginger-garlic paste and fry for about 1 minute until fragrant.
Add chopped onions and tomatoes to the pan and sauté until onions turn translucent.
Sprinkle red chili powder and coriander powder and mix well.
Add the cooked beans along with their cooking liquid.
Simmer on low heat for 15–20 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Garnish with freshly chopped cilantro (Dhaniya).
Serve hot with steamed rice for a traditional Nepali meal.

Boil or grill the chicken pieces until fully cooked, ensuring the meat is tender and no longer pink inside.
Cut the cooked chicken into small, bite-sized cubes for even mixing and easy eating.
Heat mustard oil in a pan until it starts to shimmer, releasing its characteristic aroma.
Add fenugreek seeds and allow them to crackle briefly, being careful not to burn them.
Add finely chopped garlic and fry lightly until fragrant, infusing the oil with flavor.
Place the cooked chicken cubes in a large mixing bowl.
Add chili powder, turmeric, ground cumin, ground coriander, and salt. Mix well to coat the chicken evenly with the spices.
Pour the garlic and fenugreek-infused oil over the chicken and mix thoroughly to combine all flavors.
Add chopped onions, sliced green chilies, and fresh coriander leaves to the mixture.
Squeeze in fresh lemon juice for tanginess and balance of flavors.
Mix everything thoroughly until all ingredients are evenly combined.
Serve the spiced chicken hot with chiura (beaten rice) for a traditional Nepali dish.

Boil the noodles in plenty of water until they are soft but still firm to the bite. Drain thoroughly and set aside to prevent sticking.
Heat a small amount of oil in a pot over medium heat.
Sauté finely chopped garlic, grated ginger, and sliced onions until fragrant and lightly golden.
Add chopped carrots, cabbage, capsicum, and tomato to the pot. Stir-fry for a few minutes until the vegetables are slightly tender but still retain some crunch.
Add chili powder, turmeric, and salt to taste, stirring well to coat the vegetables evenly with the spices.
Pour in vegetable broth or water and bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer gently for a few minutes to allow the flavors to combine.
Add the cooked noodles to the soup and stir gently to mix everything together.
Add soy sauce and freshly chopped coriander for flavor and aroma.
Simmer for another minute, then serve the soup hot, ensuring the noodles and vegetables are evenly distributed.

Cut the mutton into medium-sized, even cubes to ensure they cook uniformly.
In a large mixing bowl, combine yogurt, freshly prepared ginger-garlic paste, mustard oil, and freshly squeezed lemon juice. Mix well until smooth.
Add turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix thoroughly so that the spices are evenly distributed throughout the marinade.
Add the mutton cubes to the marinade and coat each piece completely. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a lid and refrigerate for at least 6–8 hours or overnight for deeper flavor penetration.
Preheat the charcoal grill or oven to high heat. Ensure the grill is clean and lightly oiled to prevent sticking.
Thread the marinated mutton pieces onto skewers, leaving small gaps between pieces to allow even cooking.
Place the skewers on the grill and cook, turning occasionally to ensure all sides are evenly charred.
While grilling, baste the mutton pieces with a little mustard oil to enhance flavor and prevent drying out.
Grill until the mutton is tender, slightly charred on the edges, and cooked through. Internal temperature should reach around 70–75°C (160–167°F).
Remove the skewers from the grill and let them rest for a few minutes.
Serve the grilled mutton hot alongside chiura (beaten rice) and your favorite achar (pickles) for an authentic Nepali experience.

Boil the noodles in plenty of water until they are just soft, ensuring they are al dente and not overcooked. Drain thoroughly and set aside to prevent sticking.
Heat a wok or large frying pan over medium-high heat and add a small amount of oil.
Sauté finely chopped garlic, freshly grated ginger, and sliced onions until fragrant and the onions turn translucent.
Add your choice of vegetables such as carrots, bell peppers, cabbage, and capsicum. Stir-fry on high heat for a few minutes to retain their crispness.
Add soy sauce, chili sauce, salt, and freshly ground black pepper. Stir well to coat the vegetables evenly with the sauces.
Add the boiled noodles to the wok and toss everything thoroughly so that the noodles are evenly mixed with the vegetables and sauces.
Cook on high flame for 2–3 minutes, stirring continuously to heat the noodles through and slightly caramelize the sauces.
Garnish with chopped spring onions for freshness and aroma.
Serve the noodles hot immediately to enjoy the perfect texture and flavor.

In a large bowl, combine rice flour and all-purpose flour, mixing them thoroughly to ensure an even base.
Add sugar, ghee, cardamom powder, and mashed ripe banana to the flour mixture. Mix well to form a smooth batter.
Gradually add milk or water, little by little, to achieve a thick but flowing consistency that can be piped or spooned easily.
Cover the batter and let it rest for 1–2 hours at room temperature to allow slight fermentation and flavor development.
Heat oil in a deep pan or kadhai over medium heat, ensuring it is hot enough for frying but not smoking.
Pour or pipe small circular shapes of batter into the hot oil, keeping enough space between each for even cooking.
Fry the shapes on medium heat until golden brown on one side, then carefully flip to fry the other side until fully cooked and golden.
Remove the fried pieces using a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve the treats warm for the best taste and texture.

Wash and pit lapsi (लप्सी) fruits.
Cut into small pieces.
Roast mustard seeds (तोरी) and fenugreek seeds (मेथी) lightly.
Add chopped garlic (लसुन) and green chilies (हरियो खुर्सानी), sauté briefly.
Add turmeric powder (बेसार) and red chili powder (खुर्सानी पाउडर).
Add the lapsi pieces and salt (नून) to taste.
Cook for a few minutes until the fruits soften but retain shape.
Add a little mustard oil (तेल) and mix well.
Cool and serve as a tangy side dish with rice or dal.

Wash basmati rice (बासमती चामल) and soak for 30 minutes.
Heat oil (तेल) in a pan and sauté chopped onions (प्याज), garlic (लसुन), and ginger (अदुवा) until golden.
Add chopped vegetables (carrots, beans, peas) and stir-fry for 5 minutes.
Add biryani masala (बिरयानी मसला), turmeric powder (बेसार), chili powder (खुर्सानी पाउडर), and salt (नून).
Layer partially cooked rice over the vegetables.
Add saffron-infused milk (केसरी दूध) and cook on low heat, covered, for 15–20 minutes.
Garnish with fresh cilantro (धनिया) and fried onions.
Serve hot with raita or achar.

Marinate chicken (कुखुराको मासु) with yogurt (दही), ginger-garlic paste (अदुवा-लसुनको पेस्ट), turmeric (बेसार), chili powder (खुर्सानी पाउडर), and salt (नून) for 2 hours.
Wash basmati rice (बासमती चामल) and soak for 30 minutes.
Heat oil (तेल) in a pan and sauté onions (प्याज) until golden.
Add marinated chicken and cook until half done.
Layer partially cooked rice over the chicken.
Add biryani masala (बिरयानी मसला) and saffron-infused milk (केसरी दूध).
Cover tightly and cook on low heat for 20 minutes.
Garnish with fried onions and fresh cilantro (धनिया).
Serve hot with raita or achar.

Boil noodles (नूडल्स) until just soft, drain and keep aside.
Heat oil (तेल) in a wok.
Sauté chopped garlic (लसुन), ginger (अदुवा), and onion (प्याज) until fragrant.
Add carrots, cabbage, bell peppers, and capsicum.
Stir-fry for 3–4 minutes on high heat.
Add soy sauce (सोया सस), chili sauce (खुर्सानी सस), salt (नून), and pepper (मिर्च).
Add the boiled noodles and toss well to combine.
Cook for 2–3 minutes on high flame.
Garnish with spring onions (हरियो प्याज) and serve hot.

Mix rice flour (चामलको पिठो) with water and a pinch of salt (नून) to make a soft dough.
Divide the dough into small portions and roll into oval shapes.
Prepare filling by mixing chaku (गुड़) and grated coconut (नारियल).
Fill each dough piece with the sweet mixture.
Seal the edges carefully and shape into the traditional Yomari form.
Steam the Yomari in a steamer for 10–12 minutes until cooked.
Serve warm as a traditional Newari dessert.

Soak chickpeas overnight in water, then drain thoroughly.
In a food processor, combine chickpeas, onion, garlic, parsley, cilantro, cumin, coriander, salt, pepper, and baking powder. Pulse until mixture is coarse and grainy, not smooth.
Transfer to a bowl, cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour or overnight.
Form the mixture into small patties or balls about 1.5 inches in diameter.
Heat oil in a deep pan to 350°F (175°C). Fry falafel in batches for 3-4 minutes until golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels.
Warm the flatbreads or pita bread.
Spread hummus on each wrap, add lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, and pickles.
Place 3-4 falafel pieces in the center.
Drizzle with tahini sauce and add a squeeze of lemon juice.
Wrap tightly and serve immediately.
